intro: Sagina crassicaulis, commonly known as broad-stemmed mossweed, is a low-growing annual plant native to temperate regions of the Northern Hemisphere. It belongs to the family Montiaceae and is characterized by its prostrate growth habit and small, fleshy leaves. The plant produces tiny, white to pale blue flowers that are clustered in dense inflorescences. It thrives in disturbed soils and is often found in fields, roadsides, and waste areas. Its botanical features make it a common weed in agricultural and natural habitats.
